titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Ira Hutchinson Brainerd Scrapbook MC.103
titlestmt.author: Jacqueline Rider

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2020-12-14 08:44:37 -0500.

did.abstract: Ira Hutchinson Brainerd was an alumnus of New York University, member of the Psi Upsilon Fraternity, and author. This collection consists of his scrapbook of newspaper clippings and other documents related to his time at NYU.
did.physloc: Materials are stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please request materials at least two business days prior to your research visit to coordinate access.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Ira Hutchinson Brainerd was an alumnus of New York University, author, and legal historian.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Materials are in their original order.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Because of the assembled nature of this collection, copyright status varies across the collection. Copyright is assumed to be held by the original creator of individual items in the collection; these items are expected to pass into the public domain 120 years after their creation. Repository is not authorized to grant permission to publish or reproduce materials from this collection.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Materials found in collection; there is no documentation concerning the provenance of these materials.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Ira Hutchinson Brainerd Scrapbook; MC 103; box number; folder number; New York University Archives.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Materials place in archival folder and manuscript box.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials consist of Ira Hutchinson Brainerd's scrapbook of newspaper clippings and other documents related to his time at NYU.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: Due to the fragile nature of the original materials, researchers must use the photocopied version.
